Some of the GECCO folks might be interested in this...

Those of you on the Genetic Programming yahoo group may be aware of the 
Physical Travelling Saleman Problem (PTSP) competition being run for 
GECCO, details here:

http://cswww.essex.ac.uk/staff/sml/gecco/PTSPComp.html

I had originaly set out to solve this using none-NEAT methods but it 
soon became clear that I was taking far too long trying to work through 
some maths (my maths being a bit rusty) and so I switched to my back up 
plan of evolving a neural net controller that could navigate its way 
through a given PTSP map.

After some considerable head banging & hair pulling I finally hit upon a 
good controller model and fitness function that can solve the specific 
problem defined for the GECCO competition - unfortunately it is now 3 
days after the closing date. I did submit a solution prior to the 
deadline but it was quite a poor one, visiting only 10 of the 30 
coordinates.

Anyway here is the league table that shows my entries from today:

http://algoval.essex.ac.uk:8080/ptsp/League.jsp?mapName=Map-30-g5

The SharpNEAT entries are some way off the best solutions, however the 
ANN controller is only half of the problem,  the actual route followed 
by the controller is actually the shortest route (optimum TSP solution) 
and there is therefore potential for using the evolved controller in a 
conventional evolutionary search to find a better route.

Also note the 'Bob/PerlGP/anymap' entries which I understand to be using 
a similar approach using an evolved controller - and judging by the 
numbers Bob is generating I'm guessing he's probably using the same 
route as me.

I'll probably post more details of this next week. It's also likely 
there will be a general discussion on the GP group after the PTSP GECCO 
session on Tuesday.

Regards,

Colin.
